skill.name: Global Commenting
skill.description: Write self-documenting code with minimal, evergreen comments that explain complex logic without describing recent changes or temporary fixes. Use this skill when writing code comments, documentation strings, explaining complex algorithms, clarifying business logic, or deciding whether code needs comments. Apply when working with any source code files where comments or documentation might be added, ensuring comments remain relevant, helpful, and focused on explaining why rather than what the code does, while preferring clear code structure and naming over excessive commenting.

skill.author: EIS-ITS

security_audit.summary: Pure prompt-based skill providing documentation guidelines. No executable code, network access, filesystem access, or command execution capabilities. Contains only SKILL.md file with commenting best practices.

content.value_statement: Poor or outdated comments create confusion and technical debt. This skill provides clear guidelines for writing comments that explain why decisions were made, helping developers create self-documenting code that stays relevant over time.
actual_capabilities: Guides comment placement decisions for any programming language
Explains why comments should focus on business logic over code descriptions
Helps identify when to refactor code instead of adding comments
Provides guidelines for evergreen comments that remain relevant
Assists with docstrings and function documentation
limitations: Does not generate documentation from code automatically
Does not enforce comments through linting or CI/CD
Does not remove outdated comments without user approval
Does not parse or analyze existing codebases

use_cases.title: Writing clear comments
use_cases.description: Add meaningful comments that explain complex logic and non-obvious decisions in your codebase.

use_cases.title: Improving documentation
use_cases.description: Review and improve existing comments for clarity and relevance during code reviews.

use_cases.title: Documenting APIs
use_cases.description: Create consistent documentation strings and API comments following established standards.

prompt_templates.title: Add function comment
prompt_templates.prompt: Add a clear comment to this function that explains why this approach was chosen, focusing on the business logic and any non-obvious decisions.

prompt_templates.title: Review existing comments
prompt_templates.prompt: Review these comments and flag any that are outdated, redundant, or could be replaced by clearer code or variable names.

prompt_templates.title: Document algorithm
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a comment that explains the algorithm approach and why it solves this problem better than alternatives.

prompt_templates.title: Improve self-documentation
prompt_templates.prompt: Suggest how to make this code more self-explanatory through naming and structure, and where comments would still add value.

best_practices: Explain why the code exists, not what it does
Prefer clear naming and structure over excessive comments
Keep comments evergreen - avoid documenting temporary fixes
Remove or update outdated comments when refactoring
anti_patterns: Commenting obvious code (like incrementing a counter)
Using comments to disable code (commented-out blocks)
Writing comments that describe recent changes instead of code intent
Adding comments that will become outdated with future changes

faq.question: What programming languages does this skill support?
faq.answer: All languages. Guidelines apply universally to any source code file.

faq.question: How detailed should comments be?
faq.answer: Comments should explain non-obvious decisions. Clear code needs fewer comments.

faq.question: Can this skill generate API documentation?
faq.answer: It provides guidelines for writing docstrings but does not auto-generate documentation.

faq.question: Is my code data stored or transmitted?
faq.answer: No. This is a prompt-only skill that provides guidelines. No code leaves your machine.

faq.question: How is this different from a linter?
faq.answer: This provides conceptual guidance, not automated enforcement or code analysis.

faq.question: Should I use comments or better variable names?
faq.answer: Prefer self-documenting code through naming. Use comments when naming cannot convey intent.
